title: What will President Biden’s approval rating be as of 13 August 2021, according to FiveThirtyEight?
preds: It's past midnight EDST.  I will be surprised if there's any additional updating.

Question closes Friday, 8/13/21, with 538's polling data (presumably) for that day "accessed" on Monday, 8/16/21. So one more day of new polls - if any - on 538, it seems to me.  Biden's overall approval rating at 538 on Friday, 8/6/21 was 50.2%. Nearly a week's worth of new polls effectively hasn't changed that. The six most recent polls used by 538 have averaged a 50% approval rating for Biden.  ..A (last) guess is that it will take one - or more likely two - new, below-50% polls for Biden on Friday (depending upon 538's weighting) to drag the aggregate to 50.0 or lower

Wow! this one turned out to be exciting down to the wire.  I do know for certain that Biden's approval will dip very seriously eventually, but this is still very early in his administration.   Looking at past all Presidents have had troubles.  What's different with Obama, Trump and now Biden is smoother.  More people stubbornly dug in - before people looked at what was going on and make judgement about the president - so more up and down according to what was happening. But look at Obama's.  Guy much more charismatic than Biden and he went below 50% after one year.  Biden will be sooner and much more severe.  Obama, even if you dislike his policies, was just such a likeable guy that it was hard to disapprove.

Somehow stopped the slide. 50.2% today and seems to be trending there. I panicked a week ago when he suddenly shed 1.3% between 8/1 and 8/6, but I'd be insanely shocked if he dipped because of anything today. If we do slip, I'll admit I was a bit too confident in this and lament that I missed the mark by such a small amount. That's definitely an emotional argument because honestly I should be taking that into account since the buckets are absolute. Just chuckling a bit at how 50.0% will make my score not great, but 50.1% will be totally fine. Showing my human biases.

Going on the basis that the question closes in 11hours and the site has already been updated with today’s polls, so unlikely to see many new polls published before the question closes.  So premise here is that the 50.2pc is the final result.
There are 4 letters to describe my thought-out rationale for this forecast: idfk.
Recent Fox News poll helped Joe out. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-approval-rating/, https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/other/president-biden-job-approval-7320.html

SIMULATION: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/biden_approval/biden_monte_carlo.py
DATA : https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/biden_approval/approval.csv
CURRENT APPROVAL INPUT: 50.3%
EXPECTED APPROVAL OUTPUT: {
"Lower than 45.0%": 0.00%,
"Between 45.0% and 50.0%, inclusive": 36.86%,
"Higher than 50.0% but lower than 55.0%": 63.14%,
"55.0% or higher": 0.00%
}
NOTE: Simulation updated to reflect the appropriate evaluation date.

I don't know if any polls will come out between now and resolution but I'm wondering if maybe since the recent polls are all around 49 or 50 that another day or two could drop an older poll or two (likely with higher rating) out of the average, making bucket 2 most likely? Or perhaps that's not how it works and maybe it only drops old polls when new polls are released.

538's all-polls index is currently at 50.0 for Biden. Highly-'graded' recent YouGov and HarrisX polls measure Biden's approval rate at 48% and 50% respectively. (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-approval-rating/) 
Real Clear Politics current poll average for Biden is 49.7 (https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/other/president-biden-job-approval-7320.html)  https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/7436/What-will-Biden's-538-job-approval-index-be-for-Aug-17
At 50% as of August 11, 11:44AM; this is a nail biter!!  With the top bin being inclusive I will place more weight there for the time being but could easily go either way now.
Revising to 70/30.  Seems like he may squeeze through above 50%.
Disapproval went down which is a sign to me that things will stay the same or get better for Biden in the next several days. But I'd give this 2:1 odds.
Infrastructure package may help Biden beginning now. Will revisit forecast after (any) 538 update tomorrow

At 50.4% w/ 200 days worth of data
Avg. DoD delta: +0.056%
Largest swings: +3.81% / -3.683%
57/200 days constituting a drop that would satisfy "Between 45.0% and 50.0%, inclusive" -- 28.5% Too little too late, but I'd say the crowd has done well in estimating.

With the historic $1Billion infrastructure bill passing the Senate, I believe Biden will most likely not slip below the 50% approval in the next few days. https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2021/08/10/senate-infrastructure-bill-vote-biden/
50.2 . . .2 days until this closes. . . oh man, talk about a squeaker!
With only 3 days to go and a stable current approval, it is unlikely to change much.
just a few days left and ticked up slight the last couple days.
It crept up .2 today and the infrastructure bill is poised to pass the Senate tomorrow, so I'm hopeful it'll stay above 50% for the next week.

"55.0% or higher": 0.00%
}
NOTE: Amazing! The simulation exactly matches the crowd forecast!
Down to 50.2% with 5 days left, looks like it'll be close
Adjusting towards the 45-50% number based on today's news from Afghanistan.  His numbers are on the border now, and this will make them get worse - there is still enough time before resolution.
Just a little above 50% now, and falling.
Pre-delta variant driven surge in cases, would have assigned about two-thirds probability of rating between 50 and 55%.

The President's approval rating continues to drift lower due to changes in Covid cases, immigration and an uncertain economy. Americans appear to like President Biden but fewer Americans especially independents are willing to give President Biden the benefit of the doubt.
It's at 50.2% today (07. Aug). I think below or higher 50% are as likely.
I'm moving back up assuming the good economic report today will provide a bump in the final days.
This still depends on what polls come in in the next week. Some are definitely more negative in general than others, so there's increased chance of dipping under 50%

It's at 50.2 right now and trending downward. I was surprised at how much it has gone down, because partisanship is so strong these days, which had created a lot of resistance to going down too much or up too much, same as when Trump was president. Good article here on the situation, with some forces such as the delta variant and economic pessimism working against Biden's approval rating: https://cookpolitical.com/analysis/national/national-politics/bidens-ratings-slip-its-more-just-delta-fears

I'm surprised by his current rating.  I expected it would fall, but I didn't foresee it falling so much in the last few days.  I am thinking that it all hinges on COVID (does it get worse?) and infrastructure (will a bi-partisan bill pass?).  My current forecast is way too strong considering how close his rating is to 50%.  Dang!

Wow.  At 50.2% as of Aug 6, pretty steep drop so suddenly.  Given past % moves I'd say it's very close to 50/50 between the two buckets with a slight lean towards 50-55%.  However, I'll take into consideration the crowd forecast and meet in the middle there so I don't get burned should it turn positive again. Will start to monitor this every day.
Americans are not  happy about his policies on the Alaska pipeline, the handling of the pandemic nor the rising cost of living
The drop from the last two weeks was strong enough that it might dip under 50%, although it is likely just noise.

What a drop it has been. In 5 days the approval rating has dropped from 51.5% to 50.2% - shedding 1.3 percentage points. It's really not that much further downward and there has not been anything that's really under Biden's actual control at the moment causing this. Potential upside - bipartisan infrastructure deal.
Potential and very likely downside - continued issues with COVID and people blaming the President for these mask mandates and new restrictions on their lives. I'm shading toward the downside after having believed for most of this poll that there was no way we would be here. If we dip below in a few days, I'll likely increase that percentage.

50.2, close to a coin flip. I think the momentum has some chance of continuing, as (rightly or wrongly) a surge in delta cases will weigh on favorability, as well as the increasing reaction to it (shot and mask mandates). On the other hand, very little time left.
The question closes in a week, and his popularity is falling. It will be close to 50%, but it's hard to determine which side at this point.

With increasing disapproval, that may accelerate bin 1 and 2.

Dropped again.  Think weighting’s and age are affecting current score and so as all the recent polls are close to 50pc we have to think it will keep dropping.  Depends now on how many polls are published in the next week.
At 50.4. Given my volatility assumptions, it's about a 0.44 standard deviation move to get to 50.0 (note that the 45-50 bucket includes 50.0).

Don't quite understand the "blame Biden for COVID resurgence among the unvaccinated" (mainly in certain U.S. states), but will adjust some for currently dropping approval numbers: https://www.politico.com/news/2021/08/04/joe-biden-coronavirus-approval-rating-502439 https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-approval-rating/

This is exciting.  Looks like it will be close.  For so long it just didn't look like it was going to move much away from about 52%.  I knew eventually his approval will plummet, but wasn't sure if by 13 August.  But now it looks like it's headed to below 50%.  And maybe below 45%!
I got to watch this closely because maybe will drop below 45%.
Holly cow!  I've always been very sure his approval would drop precipitously, but not sure by 13 August.  Finally people are waking up to what a total disaster this administration is.

SIMULATION: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/biden_approval/biden_monte_carlo.py

CURRENT APPROVAL INPUT: 50.6%
EXPECTED APPROVAL OUTPUT: {
"Lower than 45.0%": 0.00%,
"Between 45.0% and 50.0%, inclusive": 31.01%,
"Higher than 50.0% but lower than 55.0%": 68.88%,
"55.0% or higher": 0.11%
}
NOTE: Using the simulation as a guide, but biasing toward the crowd for my actual estimates.
Definitely not spiking to 55% or higher with the current state of affairs. I'm still very confident in 50-55%, but will keep 5% in the 45-50% range because we might dip just enough at the wrong time.
Baseline forecast based on current approval rating
As of 8/3/21 Biden's approval rating on 538 is 50.9% and while it is steadily decreasing the rate of fall is not sufficient to drop below 50% before 8/16/21

Maybe I'm just rationalizing an overreliance on recent data like I have in the past, but I'm bumping the <= 50 bucket a bit. Still a low outside rate, but I think I was underestimating the size of the effect from the delta variant surge in past forecasts to justify a higher 50-55% probability (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1307905).  The daily numbers in the curve that they're showing are an average over a fairly long time period, it's an average of polynomial regressions over 10, 20, and 30 days. I'd noted previously we haven't seen much of an effect from the delta variant, but that may be because it's still weighting polls from up to a month ago. We have 10 days left, which will means we'll cycle out the polls from July 4 - July 14 and add in a new set of current polls. We'll both add new less favorable polls, and remove old more favorable polls, which should extend the downward trend, even if nothing changes with the actual population-level approval rate in the next week and a half. That said, it's very easy to see from the historical data that dips like the current one don't always last. Seemingly random jumps out of nowhere aren't uncommon. We may be at a local minimum which we'll regress back to the mean from, a pattern we've seen countless times for this curve. It'll come down to what polls come out when, and how the FiveThirtyEight bias adjuster changes them and polynomial smoother treats them, which is fairly opaque. We're at the lowest level ever and still have 0.9% to fall, probably more if we regress to the mean, which is pretty far in this context.  Lastly, it's not even clear that his approval rating has dropped enough recently, despite the curve results. Looking at polls since July 27, they still skew towards above 50% (look at each poll's difference from 50% times its weight). Instead the dip could be from the phasing out of polls from late June, which appear more favorable than recent polls, even if the trend over the past couple weeks has been minimal. The curve will probably continue to fall, but it's a question of degree and timing. With so much unknown, its difficult to deviate much further from the very low outside rate for this question.

50.9 today and all the recent averages are close to 50pc.  Not many recent dots over 50pc.  
10 days to go and weighting if older, higher approval rates polls will reduce daily.  Also the polls closer to 50pc have got greater weighting in the calcs.  The 4 new polls today over 50pc are only just over 50pc and have a lower weighing than the recent under 50pc polls.
It could drop below 50pc now.  Of course depends on the polls in the next few days, but the trend is downwards.

His approval rating continues to fall. Depending on the two infrastructure bills, this could shift up a little bit, but with COVID weighing heavily on people, I think it's more likely that his rating will continue to fall, although I think he has a floor of support at or above 45%.

recently his approval rating has been decreasing and is approaching the 50% mark, so I think it'll be very close to 50% but am giving the edge to it staying above.
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-approval-rating/

Adjusting back upwards, I've really waffled on this one. Delta has been playing out and we haven't seen a big enough effect on approval ratings to justify a lower bet. Linreg since 4/24 would put us at 51.2% on the close date, and there's only been one date in that 101 day timeframe with a gap between the actual value and the linreg of more than 1.2%. So outside rate from that approach would be 1%. Will keep watching. There's a chance that delta will cause an effect but its delayed by a few days because the polls take time to do. The polls they cite are mostly from 3-4 days ago. That situation is changing rapidly, though Fauci said he doesn't expect lockdowns, so we probably won't see a seismic shift in policy to produce a sudden shift in approval like we'd need to see to go below 50%. There's also the recent eviction moratorium fiasco, though that'll be something to watch in a month or so as court rulings accumulate and evictions can happen in volume.
Roughly 1.25% standard deviation assumed over next 2 weeks

For July 30 its 51,5%. It has never been below 50% since election day, so it's highly unlikely that it will be below that in two weeks. It has been higher than 55% once (March 22), but looking at the numbers at the moment is seems virtually impossible.
Dropped to 51 per cent and falling. Not a lot of time left, but there are a number of issues that are reducing his popularity. A majority of the country thinks his policies are increasing inflation.
tightening while still balancing against the simulation I ran previously: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1313413

I'm compensating for previous predictions.  13 August is not very far away and he's still at 51.5.   Obama was a little higher at this time but dropping fast and went below after about 1 year.  Carter was at 66.6% at this time!!  Carter ended up well below 50% for much of his presidency and bottom out below 30%.   I think Biden much worst than both Obama and Carter and so should be really bad eventually.  Just not sure about 13 August.
ticking down slightly to the full downside risk from the "outside view" from the simulation I ran previously: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1313413
Tick down to 51.4. Rising mask debate isn’t going to help, and despite bipartisan infrastructure deal I think it’s close to impossible he get a large polling bump in next 2 weeks.

For the last six months it has always been between 50 and 55, so it would be completely surprising if it would not be in this margin in two and a half weeks. Rising Corona cases or an unforeseeable political conflict could be a challenge, but the probability is very low.

Attempting to take the baseline (he's been 51%<X<55% all year, but with a clearly visible, but mild drop off over time. I don't expect any legislative breakthrough before 8/16 that would reverse the slow decline in his approval. Hedging with a minor allocation to something volatile happening.
I see no developments in the next few weeks that will change the deeply entrenched parisan positions.

His approval seems fairly steady although it is dipping a bit. I think the risks of a catastrophic dip or increase in his ratings have essentially fallen to 0. The infrastructure deal announced yesterday may help a bit, but the increase in COVID cases and the soon to be announced vaccine mandate for federal workers could hurt him somewhat. Additionally, immigration is still a huge risk for Biden. Lastly, progressives are starting to get impatient for his American Families Plan and student debt cancellation (if or when it happens).

this is definitely a very interesting question.  It looks like it could be close.  I'm kind of surprise there could be so many who approve of Biden.  He is  a weak, demented, impotent leader and reminds me of Jimmy Carter.  At this time Jimmy still had well over 60% approval.  But after about a year his weakness showed through and he became very unpopular.  Same thing will happen to Creepy Joe, but I think much worse. And I think Jimmy is a good man, just a weak leader.  Biden, on the other hand, is evil to the core.

SIMULATION: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/biden_approval/biden_monte_carlo.py
DATA : https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/biden_approval/approval.csv
CURRENT APPROVAL INPUT: 51.89%
EXPECTED APPROVAL OUTPUT: {
    "Lower than 45.0%": 0.01%,
    "Between 45.0% and 50.0%, inclusive": 13.06%,
    "Higher than 50.0% but lower than 55.0%": 83.69%, 
    "55.0% or higher": 3.24%
}
NOTE: Using a starting approval of 51.89% and simulating a random walk based on Biden's approval fluctuations from now until August 13th gives a ~13% chance of an approval below 50% and a ~3% chance of an approval above 55%. This is a good start for an outside view, but I suspect partisan influences put a relatively low ceiling on Biden's approval, so I'll go with the crowd's lower 1% estimate. Similarly, I suspect Biden will have a relatively high floor, but this is probably more subject to erosion due to exogenous events, so I'll give the 45-50% bucket just a little bit higher odds than the crowd.
Update: If "hard" infrastructure bill is passed it may help Biden's larger agenda, etc. https://apnews.com/article/joe-biden-government-and-politics-business-c5e6ce9620ad98687cabb678121042a3

May be able hang in there above 50% with less than three weeks to go in the question: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-approval-rating/ FWIW the most recent two polls listed above weren't 'great'..

I am lowering my forecast to reflect negative developments regarding the Biden Presidency--remember everything is the President's fault. Rising prices and coronavirus restrictions and cases will impact Biden's approval rating but I do not think it will be a sharp reduction as his base remains loyal and independents are divided. Death totals in Blue states are key.
Waiting to see what trend persists.

Approval rating has not been 55% since March and his recent slide has been reversed since the $300 child tax credits started hitting bank accounts. Definitely by far the most likely scenario for us which has been my opinion all along. Leaving the 5% chance that a bipartisan infrastructure deal could launch him into the 55+% range just in time for this poll to end. He won't stay there so it is all about timing and how much of a bump that gives him.
(This is compensating for prior forecasts. I'm currently posed to lose ~0.04 points or so when this resolves as 50-55 and I'm not convinced enough that the crowd is wrong.)
Tacking back to center to compensate earlier forecasts
Not trending down fast enough, still a chance with delta and all but looking less likely

The volatility in Biden's 538 approval rating is remarkably low. Ie, the 538 approval rating has been more stable than for most previous presidents. This is will partly caused by stability in Biden's approval rating, but also because 538 more polling data now than it did for previous presidents, leading to more stable estimates. The This increased stability could make for a more stable future forecast, especially as the forcasting timeline is only 3ish weeks outs. However, Biden's 538 approval rating rides much closer to the 50% boundary (currently 52%) than most previous presidential candidate, meaning that even a relatively minor negative event could tip him into the below 50% category. Moreover, the 538 approval has a negative drift, which increases the odds further. Without an explicit model, it is hard to factor come up with reliable estimates.
Any news that would change his approval rating at this point would be a 9/11 style attack, stability is the name of the game.

Over next three weeks, assuming a 2 month 2.5% standard deviation, a move down to 50% would be a 1.67Z event. Skewing a bit, not really allowing much for the above 55% scenario given that that was the highest Biden has ever been and back then conditions were extremely supportive to him.
His approval rating is falling on 538, and Gallup shows an even greater drop. Lowering odds on being above 50%
sitting right in middle of 50.0 - 55.0% with only a few weeks before 13 August.

Well, I think 52% have the head up their rears.  We have a president in bed with big tech censoring free speech.  Throw out First Amendment.  Hell, throw out the constitution.  But my job here is to predict the approval rating of Biden and just looking at history so far, it's pretty certain it will stall in current bin: 50.0% - 55.0%.

Revising 50-55 up.  He hasn't been out of that range since March 23rd (when he was higher).  More probability to a break to the downside, since big negative event seems more likely than bit positive one.

It's been 50.0% to 55.0% everyday since inauguration except for a couple times it was slightly above 55.0%.  Outside of something dramatic happening, I don't see any chance going above 55.0.  And now after more than 180 days still in middle of the 50 - 55 range.   Trump and Obama have fairly smooth curves and Biden is the same so far.  Before Obama all very volatile with huge gains or drops.  But I think those always were result of big dramatic events.  So, only way to see Biden's approval dramatically change is if there is a huge dramatic event. Also, today, Americans are more partisan, even though there are many non-affiliated registered voters.  Back during Nixon, Johnson, Kennedy, Eisenhower, at time all enjoyed high approval so had support across political parties.  Of course, Johnson had Vietnam that dragged him down.  Today, we are more entrenched and for Biden, Trump and Obama, many stay approve or disapprove no matter what happens.  Much more sticky today.

23 days to go with 52.3% approval.
His disapproval rating is pretty much stable for the past 4 weeks. And his approval rating was also overall stable, and never jumped (up or down) more  than 2% in a period of about a month.  Also, not sure how much it could play a role. But oil price is not increasing any more, in fact it's decreasing compared to a couple of weeks ago, down from 77 in early June to 69. I believe that's also helpful; not destructive, for the least.
Due to strong partisanship momentums and the stability in Biden's rating so far, I would expect it with a very high probability to end up at 50%-55%, and I think the crowd odds of .83 are too low.

His approval has been relatively stable since the beginning of his presidency. I think his approval rating could only go down at this point. His approval has been hit by immigration, and the news that there were more migrants at the border in June, and a federal judge ruling DACA illegal will only put more pressure on Biden. https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/16/us/politics/migrant-families-homeland-security.html?searchResultPosition=1 Immigration has been the one issue that no president or Congress has been able to tackle effectively, so this can only hurt not help Biden. Additionally, if the bipartisan infrastructure bill fails or if the $3.5 trillion plan ends up going nowhere, that will hurt him with progressive groups, which will lower his rating. I can't really see his rating going above 55%, unless something extraordinary were to happen.
Uptick in numbers. Now you’d need a 2.5% decline in less than a month. Also on the margin China escalation will help rather than hurt him.

Like most presidential approval rating trend is downward ticking in first year (outside of extraneous events and incidents) With COVID ticking up and vaccinations stalling, would be hard to see any big wins that push him upward substantially

It's going to be close.  I strongly despise Biden and Harris and most of the whole woke crap Democratic party so that probably clouds my judgement on this.  But it's fun to see his rating drop and it will drop well below 50% - I'm just not sure by 13 August.  I'm compensation my earlier predictions where I'm not optimistic it will dip below 50%.

51.1%,  falling, and about a month to go.
It can change 1.0% in 3 days. OTOH, I just scored poorly on a question because I didn't believe the outcome of a Monte Carlo, and the Monte Carlo that @slapthepancake has done suggests that he'll stay above 50%. So, since I was at 87% for above 50%, I'm going to split the difference between that and @slapthepancake. Not the most sophisticated logic, I know, but the best I can do with the time I have.

I knew his rating would dip below 50%, just don't know when.  My inclination earlier was to predict so, but numbers seems to stick at around 52% for a while.  Obama - a better president, more charismatic and being at least part black helps - but he dipped below 50% after about one year.  I figure Biden has to faster.  And really he is an awful president, babbles non-sense most of the time, is lost and confused most of the time, is creepy around young girls.  Also, gas prices nearing $4/gallon, Mexican border crisis, inflation, lot more divisive politics, etc. etc.  I just think a lot of leftist are being stubborn and not seeing how screwed up Biden and most of the Democratic Party is.  Many leftist just don't want to see reality and cling to delusion that Biden, the Democratic Party and all this Woke crap is OK. Anyway his rating is indeed headed south of 50%.

Currently at 51.2%, his low point. More strong economic news and the first disbursements of Child Tax Credits could make the number go up.  Pretty much everything else could make it go down. We're in the age of thermostatic polarization so his approval rate should stay fairly steady, but there is more room to fall than increase.

51.2%, trended down as I expected. Given a 1.75% assumed monthly vol, the current probability of winding up lower than 50 is 25%, and above 55% is 1%. Skewing those numbers a bit as I think the trend is likely to continue given a lot of the easy benefits - like stimulus checks and vaccine rollout - are behind him. Also youre starting to see support erode from within the democratic base.

Looking at Biden data historically there's no chance that it would be below 50%, a Monte Carlo using historic changes has it below 50% <1% of the time, and a linear regression (it's not linear I know) puts it at above 51% if you use the slope starting from the current level. Something needs to change (or keep changing) for it to go below 50%. Approval did dip recently to around 52% (as low as 51.5%) though, so that may be the start of something. Outside rate here is probably 12% or so for below 50%, just due to ambiguity about the recent dip and chance of more change in the future. Getting an outside rate here is pretty difficult since the polling method used here only applies to like 3 presidents, and Biden hasn't been in office very long either. I've soured on the idea of analyzing much of Biden at a high level, this is down to the opinions of 1.5% or so of respondents and whether they'll change their minds. It's difficult to study that group directly obviously, but the closest group is probably voters in swing states and independents, especially considering the wide gap between Democrats and Republicans in approval (https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2021/05/presidents-approval-ratings-are-now-all-about-partisanship.html) which likely indicate a high degree of inflexibility in those groups.  For independent voters, their main reasons for support seem to have been Biden not being Trump and him bringing stability to the COVID pandemic. I do expect Biden to continue not being Trump, very confident there. The key variable there may actually be the delta variant and resurgence in COVID. If we go back to lockdowns or if COVID spreads rapidly in the US like it recently has in the UK, that may compromise their support. At lowest point of presidency, 51.6%. Outside view: Normally 1.6% vol in approval ratings is very little even over a month, and most presidents have a decline in their first summer. Inside view: Inflation surging, most of the noticeable economic stimulus (like checks) behind us, and virus may pick back up though uncertain. On the flip side, the other inside view point is that Biden's propularity, like Trump's, is extremely not volatile.  So as a custom estimate, let's call the move from the last march high to today a 3.5% move in popularity, and let's call that a 1z move over that period. That implies a 1.75% monthly volatility in approval ratings. Therefore, a 1.6% decline from here would be a -0.9 z event, about 19% likelihood.  79% for the middle band, and 2% for the top band.  Based on some directional input, I've shifted those probabilities down slightly.

A and D at zero simply reflects how rarely the approval curve has moved more than the 7% down or 4% up needed, reinforced by the unlikeliness of war or depression occurring unexpectedly. If you extend the post-May 25 downturn, B and C are basically a toss-up.  But reversion to the mean favors C, as status quo.
Down-driving factors --Legislative return to (normal) gridlock, and quarrels on reopening--are likely to remain dominant but be equally-to-less potent.
Possible other factors in next 7 weeks include climate and crime (both intense over summer)-- possible to become significant and more likely depressant. But to pass 50, the trend has to continue unabated or worse for the next 7 weeks.  I think it's still much more likely than not that the trend lessens or completes its effect by then.  Hence somewhere between 80/20 and 75/25 for C

This question seeks a percentage approval rating on a single day.  Biden's rating has been within 50-55% on nearly every day since the start of his presidency.  It may be that it is sometimes close to 55%, and it might briefly exceed 55% before August 13, but I have not found a reason that persuades me it is going to trend higher or lower and be outside this range on August 13 itself.  Comparison to past presidents at this stage of their presidency does not seem that useful given the current (greater) degree of political polarization which may account for the stability of this approval rating.  I looked only briefly, but did not notice any particular tendency for the polls (among those aggregated by 538) that are released just before the middle of a month to give Biden either a notably lower or higher rating (and of course any such impact would be limited).

Looking at Obama, he dipped below 50% after about one year after starting at 64%.  Biden Started 53% and is a lot less charismatic than Obama and demented.   Plus a lot of things going wrong.  So I expect Biden to dip below 50% with one year of taking office, but unsure if by 13 August.

Risk, in my opinion is to the upside, however, two high datapoints will be falling off which will add roughly a point to the current 2% cushion.   He is doing a masterclass in good politics.  I expect he *will* crest 55% however, my expectation is that it will take past September to do.    I rate the actual chance at 60% that I score in the money.

One of the reporters from 538 Politics had and interesting interview on CNN over the weekend talking about new trends in presidential approval polling, which of course is rooted in our increasingly polarized partisan environment, where voters have increasing black and white hard opinion about public leaders.  The reported basically stated the way Trump's approving could never broke 50% and was predominantly between 40% and 45% during his term, polling on Biden is showing the same trend, except for him the numbers are remaining between 50% and 55%.  Something similar was seen for Obama, about 45% to 52%.  The conclusion was that spikes and deep dips in public approval are going to become increasingly unlikely in the short term, barring massive global events, such as war or major scandals of the level never seen before in American politics or complete economic collapse.

I think the big picture is Biden and his agenda are perceived as fairly milquetoast, especially in comparison to past administrations, the economy is expected to do well in the near future, and his working level so far has been about 53.5%. Polls are noisy and fluctuate a fair bit, his honeymoon period may wear off with some groups, and economic performance in the near future may do better or worse than current expectations. His approval rating has been pretty stable so far, average daily change is -0.007%, with a SD of 0.76% and a level >=55% on 1 of 119 days. No guarantee that will persist though, like Obama dropped 9% over 80 days (day ~140 to ~220) from 60% to 51%, with the main themes around that drop seeming to be the "discourse" around the ACA, as well as over a longer timespan the novelty of the presidency wearing off and the bad economy post-recession. Trump fell about 7% from his start but that was harder to pinpoint why, probably a combination of failed healthcare reform, the Russia investigation, Charlottesville, etc.  As for outside rate factors, approval ratings do tend to fall after a "honeymoon period" when a President takes office, so that doesn't bode well. Quantifying that individual effect is super hard though, since we don't have good poll data going back more than 4 administrations or so. However, approval ratings are also strongly tied to the economy, and most people are expecting a strong economic recovery as we go into the summer post-COVID with vaccines rolling out and "pent up demand" for basically everything. There's almost 0 trend in his approval ratings over time since taking office too, but the same can mostly be said for Obama as well (though not Trump), so it may not be a great marker. Overall, the economy is expected to do well so meeting expectations may have less impact than the post-election high wearing off for some group, net effect is probably a small decrease of 1.5% or so to ~52%. As for Biden specifically, he feels far less controversial than either Obama or Trump. Obama wanted to tackle healthcare in America after the Great Recession, and Trump had no shortage of controversies. Neither of them had a recipe for steady high approval. Biden on the other hand is focusing on COVID stimulus and infrastructure, and while there's disagreement about how to do them as always, those issues as a whole are about as uncontroversial as you can get. The main points of opposition are around the economy overheating and inflation and corporate taxes, but his plans have been out for months and approval ratings have trended nowhere.  Main case for above 55 is strong economic recovery as we come out of COVID boosting approval ratings, with another being the American Families Plan or American Jobs Plan being passed without anything blowing up, though I'd expect negotiations to take longer. Considering the noise in polling (SD of 0.76) it wouldn't take much increase in baseline approval rating for there to be a good chance of 55+. Main cases for below 50 are honeymoon period wearing off and a group (especially the AOC/Bernie crowd) supporting him less, or economic issues such as a weaker than expected recovery (recent jobs report is worrying), or an off-chance of inflation-related issues if increases are persistent and concentrated in goods people actually buy instead of things like used cars. I think those are more likely than the better than expected recovery, but they'd also need a larger drop in approval rating to reach, since we're hovering around 53.5 right now.

Since most of Pres. Biden's achievements so far exhaust in unwinding 45 POTUS's legacy and executive orders, opposition may grow, despite stimulus money and all efforts in the legislative branch. Senate minority leader McConnell's (R, KY) strategy of leaving no room for maneuver might play out this summer already, when disappointment among hard core Democrat voters might begin to dent approval ratings. The current "fair" rating seems to be a bit lower than what 538 indicates, maybe at 52 per cent on the individual survey level before adjustments. To fall below 50%, the approval rating needs to decline to 49.94% on the aggregate level (due to rounding) and to 49% on the survey level "after adjustments" (which slightly favor approval at the moment) for many heavy-weight non-partisan surveys to come over the next 10 weeks.  For the time being, I find the "Apr. 8-12 Quinnipiac University" survey (weight: 1.83; AR: 48%, adjustment: +2) quite interesting, which is accompanied by similar results from
Apr. 9-12 Civiqs and
Apr. 8-11 CNBC/Hart Research/Public Opinion Strategies It appears to me this is the path approval will go, which makes me think approval will end up just on the brink between bin 2 and bin 3. Jimmy Carter, Barack Obama and even DJT may serve as historic examples for modern day presidential approval trends towards "day 210", while larger jumps upwards usually coincide with the beginning of a major armed conflict (George W. Bush, George H.W. Bush; god forbid!), and the partisan divide may prevent approval ratings higher than 55% during Biden's whole first term in office.

Initial forecast: Intense partisanship currently in the U.S. may 'cap' (almost) any president's popularity numbers by potentially limiting crossovers. It could also be speculated that such partisanship may increase chances for erosion of approval (ratings) over time. (https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/bidens-first-100-days-show-how-partisan-things-have-become/) Biden's 538 website approval rating is 52.8% on their "day 115", of May 14, 2021. I count 94 more days from 5/14/21 to August 16th (the question's data access date).  If correct that would make Aug. 16th "day 209" on 538's various polls.  As a rough comparison + picking up a bit on @numa_takeda comments below, I decided to throw D. Trump out as an unusually extra-polarizing 'outlier' (https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-news/trump-final-gallup-poll-least-popular-president-ever-1116196) and looked at 538's approval graphs for B. Obama (first term) and G.W. Bush (first term), from day 6 (first polls) through day 208. (Couldn't find day 209 polling data on either.)  Obama's approval rating dropped from 64.1% to 53.2 during the period, while G.W. Bush's rose from 46.0 to 52.3. (Bush approval was about to soar after the subsequent 9/11/01 attacks.) So not too much predictive help there, but I'll still consider Obama's first 208 days to be a bit of a potential indicator for the generally partisan U.S. electorate of today. The 2001 attacks may also be a lesson about how major events can quickly change presidential approval ratings.
